Product Title: De'Longhi Stilosa EC230.BK, Traditional Barista Pump Espresso Machine, Espresso and Cappuccino, Black
Review Description: This is a nice entry level coffee machine.Although the casing is made of plastic, the actual coffee filtering part is made of metal, and feels sturdy enough to survive the pressure it will be placed under.First thing to note is that it comes with a quick guide, and then instructions in every language except for English! I'll assume it was an oversight, but that did make things take a good half hour to then work out.First time usage, you had to run a load of water through the filter and frothing system. This did originally make a lot of loud, bad sounding noises, but after a while, it did settle down to the more re-assuring noise of high pressured steam and water.This machine requires ground coffee and cannot grind the beans. The scoop also has a built in tamper - which is used to pack the coffee down into the basket. Unfortunately because it's made of plastic, it doesn't have such a good feel, and you do worry you can't press down as hard in case you break something (though it never did happen).I did find the portafilter handle very hard to place into the machine fully, it was almost like it didn't quite fit. It meant you ended up holding the machine with one hand whilst trying to twist the handle in properly with the other.The milk frothing was a lot easier to do, and after a bit of practice it wasn't too hard to get a decent froth out of itPros- Can make a decent coffee- Decent milk frothingCons- Can be fiddly and auite hard work- The tamper is made of plastic- The handle was hard to fit properly into the machine- Instructions were missing- no milk frothing jub providedIn summary: It's not a perfect machine, but if you perservere, you can get a reasonably good expresso or cappucino out of this machine. Given the cost is Â£99, it sounds expensive, but given you can easily spend several times that for higher end machines, despite the learning curve, the resultcan be good for the money.

Product Title: De'Longhi Stilosa EC230.BK, Traditional Barista Pump Espresso Machine, Espresso and Cappuccino, Black
Review Description: Over the years, i've had a few De'Longhi espresso makers, and I've always been delighted with them - in fact, my previous model (soon to be my current model again!) has been going strong for quite a few years now.I have to say that this machine disappointed me on almost every level.I know that appearance is a very subjective thing, but personally I felt that the all-plastic appearance looked a bit cheap and tacky.Oh well.  What sort of coffee does it make?It took longer than expected to answer that question.  No matter how many times I removed and re-inserted the (plastic) water container, it just wouldn't fit properly, with the result that it took a ridiculous number of attempts and time before I finally even managed to get water to flow through the machine.In my opinion, the quality control was severely lacking here.When I finally got to make my coffee, I have to admit that I was so prejudiced against this machine that it may have put me in an overly-critical frame of mind.  And maybe if I'd stuck with this machine I'd have decided that the coffee wasn't so poor after all.But the bottom line is that I really, REALLY disliked this machine.  It's already gone for recycling, and I'm back to using my previous De'Longhi.  I can't really recommend this one at all.

Product Title: De'Longhi Stilosa EC230.BK, Traditional Barista Pump Espresso Machine, Espresso and Cappuccino, Black
Review Description: Edit - I am now really happy with this machine. I am using a more expensive brand of beans, which produces a much better crema.I really like Delonghi espresso machines - I find they survive well in hard water areas. Even though they have mainly plastic bodies, the insides are the same as the expensive brands, and I have always got great cuos of coffee from them.This one has a few extras that you don't get with the basic model: there's an on/off rocker switch - it also turns off if not in use.  The water tank is lift-out, which is great, as taking it to the sink to fill is a lot easier than having to use a jug.You don't need a pressure gauge - a green light comes on when the correct pressure has been reached; also when the water has reached the right temperature to pass through the coffee.The frother is on the right-hand side - something to bear in mind if you're placing it in a corner. All the others I've had have had it on the left.The main reason I'm not giving this a higher rating is because I can't get a good crema from it - I've tried grinding the beans coursely, finely, and everything in between, but no joy. I think this is because the metal cup that you put the coffee in has been changed from the design that they used to have - it's now missing a rubber layer inside, and looks and feels cheaper; maybe they've cut costs there. This might not be the reason why, of course. Whatever the reason, I'm not happy with the resulting brew.So I can only give it three stars. This is a little bit harsh in a way, as I really like the machine - but at the end of the day, it's all about the coffee that you have in your cup.

Product Title: De'Longhi Stilosa EC230.BK, Traditional Barista Pump Espresso Machine, Espresso and Cappuccino, Black
Review Description: A good value espresso machine that creates a decent drink without fuss or a huge price tag.The espresso machine is simple to use and whilst it does have the bells and whistles of more expensive machines it has everything you need to create a range of coffee shop drinks.This needs pre-ground coffee, you can use freshly ground if you have a grinder ( I have a spice grinder that doubles as a coffee grinder that cost me under fifteen quid a few years ago and this does a good job on coffee beans) or buy pre ground coffee grinds, if buying grinds Iâ€™d recommend going for the finer grinds designed for espresso machines as this helps the pressure build to the stage where you get the nice crema on the top of your drink.There is no pressure gauge on this machine ( one of the missing bells and whistles!) but as long as your espresso has a crema on the top you can be pretty certain that it reached optimal pressure.The steaming wand is good for frothy milk, you need to buy a separate milk jug for this if you donâ€™t already have one ( Iâ€™d recommend one with a temperature gauge along the bottom so you donâ€™t over heat the milk) when used correctly ( pointing towards the side of the jug, creating a swirl in the milk and a â€œtearingâ€ sound) this gives you nice smooth milk with lots of micro bubbles which creates a good flat white or latte.The water tank holds a good amount and is easy to fill, I have been leaving it in place and filling from my filter jug rather than straight from the tap as this gives the coffee a better taste, however when you want to  clean it, it is easy to remove and wash in the sink.The special measuring has a built in tamper on the base, when used to pack in the coffee grinds into the coffee basket it helps the pressure get up an you get the most from your grinds. This isnâ€™t the flashiest tamper but it works perfectly well and is the perfect fit for the coffee basket.In use I got a steady stream of coffee and no leaks or escaping grinds, I like to use a half pint mug with a double shot and topped up with steamed milk, my half pint mug is too big for the gap between the coffee basket and the base of the machine, I get round this by using an espresso mug and decanting this into my mug, itâ€™s not an issue and if you use a smaller cup you wonâ€™t have any problems, but if you like a big drink this is a good way around the issue.If you like an americano you can top up with hot water from the steam wand by simply choosing the water option.All things considered this is decent machine, it doesnâ€™t have all the flashy extras that some others have but it produces a decent coffee never the less and the price point is a lot less than some of the more complex machines.

Review Title: So far so good... takes a little effort
Review Description: I got this espresso maker for Christmas because I have been missing my daily iced double shot from Starbucks after moving to a town with no Starbucks :( I did a little research before purchasing this particular one, but wish I had known a few details before.  All I knew about espresso before purchasing is how to order the drink I wanted so I definitely didn't want to spend a crazy amount of money but also knew I wasn't interested in something that was going to make a less authentic drink like a pod style machine (nespresso).  So today is the first time I have used it. Takes a little time to set up, no big deal, but also more time than I was expecting to actually produce a shot of espresso... ok I can live with that...My initial plan was like ok I'll just make a couple shots & have an iced latte every day but now I feel like that may not be realistic.  I grabbed some (cheap) cafe bustelo at the store to give the machine a try, I realize there's way better espresso out there. Anyway, I made my husband and I a cappuccino & it was actually great for my very first time ever, we were pretty impressed! It actually tasted like what you'd order at a coffee shop, I guess I lucked out getting the milk/espresso ratio correct.  Wasn't too hard to use or figure out.  HOWEVER, A few things to note... first- there's a reserve tank of water in the machine and to make a shot, you either put the filter in made for one shot or two and just measure one or two scoops out of espresso and turn the knob, pretty simple.  BUT you have to manually decide when to turn the knob back aka it doesn't stop (like a coffee pot) once your shot(s) has been made  ... so basically it would run the entire reserve tank of water through unless you turn the knob back & I had no clue how to determine when to do that as a first time user, just had to guess based on how much was in the glass.  Which brings me to my next point- it does not come with any espresso shot glasses which would have been helpful to measure & better judge when to shut it off.  I just used a coffee cup which was almost too big to fit under the nozzle, not ideal.  Anyway, something I didn't realize I needed to buy separately.  Also, cleanup is NOT a breeze. It's not like making a pot of coffee and you just dump the basket and filter when you're done... because the filters are reusable in this machine you have to basically disassemble that whole part to rinse it & I'm talking remove it from the machine, scoop out and dump the grounds, unscrew the bottom, pop 4 separate pieces out of the filter, rinse each one separately, dry them off and then reassemble.  I just don't know if I was prepared to do all that every single day when in a hurry to get out of the house.  Plus if you want to use the milk frother daily you're doing even more cleaning- you have to run hot water through it then take it apart and rinse it as well after each use.  Which reminds me, I will also have to buy a milk frothing glass because that was not included and I need something that can measure for me otherwise I'm just guessing on that too.  Ok so all that being said, even the cheap espresso my first time using tasted great.  I know it will take some practice to get used to, I was just hoping it would be an easier replacement for my morning cup of coffee or spending $5 at Starbucks daily.  I am now looking into purchasing the ESE pods that can also be used in this machine instead of ground espresso... I didn't factor this expense in, they're around $35-$50 for 150 count which isn't ideal but it may be worth it if it saves time on cleanup and I can have my iced latte every day

Review Title: After 20 years of espresso obsession, surprised to report this little guy makes pretty good coffee.
Review Description: For 20 years I've obsessed on coffee and owned $500-$800 espresso machines -- Rancilio Silvia and more recently a Gaggia Classic. Bought a Stilosa as a temporary solution while the Classic is going through its yearly overhaul.The espresso from the Stilosa is more than acceptable -- it's really quite good. The pressurized portafilter does a great job -- pressurized portafilters have come a long way from 15-20 years ago. With a pressurized portafilter there's no need to tamp the coffee -- just scoop it loose into the portafilter and brew. A proper espresso grind is still helpful for flavor I think -- so put your money into a decent grinder.Another Stilosa feature is critical -- there's an actual steel boiler instead of the thermoblock that low-end espresso machines all had a few years ago. The thermoblocks could never sustain water temperature adequately so you had sour weak coffee. This boiler, while small, provides enough hot water at temperature for about 20 seconds (more than a double shot). And the portafilter is thin, lightweight aluminum so it's not robbing heat from the coffee.The other advantage of a small boiler and lightweight portafilter -- you can turn on this machine and be ready to brew in about 2-3 minutes. By contrast, the Gaggia Classic, with its big brass portafilter, really should have 15-20 minutes to warm up, and the Rancilio, with its huge brass boiler, needs 30-45 minutes.I can't speak to the steam system -- we only use this for coffee shots.But I think the performance is astonishing for the price -- kudos to the engineers at Delonghi. This beats the pants off Nespresso in my opinion and you're not paying 80 cents a shot for pods. It doesn't have the power or flexibility of a Gaggia Classic or Silvia and isn't really designed to crank out 10 drinks for a dinner party. But if all you want is a shot or two in the morning, this will do the job quite well.

Review Title: Entry-Level Espresso Machine - Great Shots, But Not Happy With The Machine Overall
Review Description: Let me start by saying that if you want a great espresso shot from a value-priced machine, this is the one for you.  The machine delivers quality shots.The machine is compact and should be able to fit on the countertop in even the smallest of kitchens.That's where the love affair ends for me. While I do like that this machine will dispense any size shot you'd like, I wish this was an OPTION and not the ONLY way to do it.  I tend to multi-task and even though it only takes a minute or two, I prefer to not have to stand next to the machine so that I can manually stop the brew.The milk frother on this machine works about how I would expect it to on an entry-level machine.  However, it also doesn't meet my expectations.  I currently use a freestanding Capresso frother. With this machine, the frother spatters droplets of milk onto the machine and countertops.  It also requires an oven mitt to remove the nozzle if I want to clean it immediately after use (which I always want to do).  The frother does not come with a cup or jug that conveniently stores on the machine, so you need to get yourself a second cup each time it is used.Most of the parts on this machine are made of plastic. Product Title: De'Longhi Stilosa Manual Espresso Machine, Latte & Cappuccino Maker, 15 Bar Pump Pressure + Manual Milk Frother Steam Wand, Black / Stainless, EC260BK
Review Title: Better than Dedica at One Third the Price
Review Description: I was reluctant to get this cheap ($85 at brick and mortar) espresso machine, but nothing ventured, nothing gained. Before using the Stilosa, I followed the cleaning instructions.Brewing espresso is easy. Fill the water reservoir as needed. Turn the knob to On to heat the water. Fill the appropriate espresso basket with grounds, tamp the grounds, insert the handle into the machine, put your cup under the spouts, turn the dial to the coffee icon, let brew for about 25 seconds, flip the switch back to On or Off, and your espresso is ready. Inserting the handle into the machine is easy, unlike the Dedica I had, which was so skinny that it would attempt to wobble away.The resulting espresso is good--even using cheap sub-barista medium roast coffee that is ground in a blade grinder. I expect that with more practice and when I use better coffee, I'll get even better espresso.  I use about 1/8th the coffee I used in my Aeropresse, which I filled half way for reasonably strong coffee. Apparently, to get even better espresso, one can cheaply hack these machines with a depressurized basket or handle available online.I dislike loud noise; the Stilosa doesn't seem too noisy.I have only used the Panarello (steam wand) to test the machine and make hot chocolate, which went well. Panarellos seem more trouble than they are worth. A simple $8 battery powered whisk will generally produce better frothed milk than most baristras can make, won't spray foam around the machine, and is easy to clean.The one thing I dislike about Stilosa is the plastic tamper, essentially a blade in waiting between the tamper and measuring spoon. To tamp espresso, you use the tamper to compress the espresso grind with about thirty pounds of pressure.  I would not be surprised if with enough use, the plastic blade-like tamper could break, with a potentially nasty hand injury resulting from the blade-like structure below. I resolved that problem by replacing the plastic tamper with a $6.99 metal tamper. DeLonghi really should include a cheap but safe metal tamper.OMG!  Wait!  Do you need a burr grinder?  Almost every hyper-concerned espresso enthusiast online recommends that one opt for a (bulky) burr grinder to grind beans into good espresso grind. They're correct if one does not fill the blade grinder, but otherwise wrong.  I get a consistent espresso grind comparable to my local barista's grind by filling a decent $20 blade grinder with beans; then I grind using short bursts, tilting the grinder slightly left, right, forward, and back. The grind blends and becomes consistent that way. The excess ground coffee goes into an airtight container for future use, a sacrilege.

Product Title: De'Longhi Stilosa Manual Espresso Machine, Latte & Cappuccino Maker, 15 Bar Pump Pressure + Manual Milk Frother Steam Wand, Black / Stainless, EC260BK
Review Description: First of all, I've worked as a barista before, so while I found this machine easy to use myself, there's a LOT of potential trial & error steps people will have to take on their own as they get used to any espresso machine. The price point should help soothe any beginner anxieties, though; worst case scenario, you live, you learn, and you save money on drive through lattes!As others have noted, the included tamper is plastic, but can (and should) be replaced with a 51mm metal tamper if you're going to use this machine frequently. For home use, you probably don't need a dedicated knock box, but if you plan on saving coffee grounds for homemade scrubs, candles, garden fertilizer, etc., it's a nice investment to make.The steaming wand is unfortunately a bit short, and definitely on the weaker end, likely to accomodate people who plan to steam their milk directly in the cup they're drinking from (lower temperatures for safety). If you really want a strong, dry foam, like for a capuccino, you'll need to buy a separate steaming device, but for your average drip coffee & latte drinker, it will suffice. Normally I'd recommend buying a metal steaming pitcher for your milk, but if you buy another steamer entirely, skip heating your milk, or heat your milk on the stove/in your microwave (horror of horrors! but it's not bad if you don't scald it), you probably won't need one. Like I said, my impression is that the attached steam wand is meant to go directly in your coffee cup, and while that has its pros (less clean-up, fewer items to buy, safer for beginners) & cons (low heat, weak foam), I can respect the trade-off in a safe, entry-level machine.On top of everything else, De'Longhi is a highly respected, high quality brand, so at this price point especially, the Stilosa model espresso machine makes an excellent graduation, birthday, anniversary, or wedding gift. And it makes a handsome addition to the appliances on any kitchen counter.

Review Title: Makes good coffee, but cheaply built and poorly designed
Review Description: Note: I've just taken delivery of a replacement unit. The original device developed a leak above the espresso head (water would stream out of a crack (?) under pressure).First the good. This coffee machine makes good espresso shots and does a fantastic job of foaming milk. My main coffee maker is a much more expensive (~$800) Breville unit, and this machine does just as good a job of making both espresso shots and if anything is quicker to foam milk. Bravo.Unfortunately, the design of the machine is clunky and they've cut corners (I would cheerfully pay $50 extra for a better designed and constructed version with more sensible controls.)1. The foaming wand is located such that you cannot rest the milk container to the side of the machine (it will be too low) or on the little platform (it will likely overbalance), so you're stuck holding the jug or balancing it precariously while foaming the milk.2. The included scoop is poorly designed and it is physically impossible to put two scoops of coffee into the two cup filter basket (as the instructions suggest). In fact, if you attempt to do this then attempting to attach the espresso head may damage the machine (and may be the cause of the leak I experienced).Also the scoop is made of cheap, bendy plastic, and isn't suitable for applying the correct pressure BUT you don't need to, as the filter basket has a pressure valve on it that ensures the proper pressure (at least while the machine is new). (Some Breville espresso makers come with a "training wheels" basket that does the same kind of thing.)3. No jug is included for foaming milk Not a huge deal, and I bought a jug separately.4. The controls are slightly odd. There is a dial with four settings, from left to right: foam, off, on, water, and a big flip lever on the side that controls the steam wand. To make a cappuccino you basically:Fill the 2 cup basket with one heaped scoop of ground coffee. Use the scoop's reverse to tamp the coffee down. (The one cup basket is pretty useless unless you want to produce demitasses or small shots.)Switch to steam mode. Wait for a green light (it's pretty quick). Flip the big lever and steam your milk. Flip it back to turn off the steam. Remove the jug. Flip the lever back on for a second to clean the wand's nozzle.Switch to on. Wait for a green light (again, pretty quick). Switch from ON to WATER and pour out the shot.Then pour the shot and milk into a cup and you're done.That's about it. For the price, it produces very good coffee. I hope it lasts longer this time (and if it does I may come back and bump up my rating).

Review Description: 2 mos in and so far, so good!I will add a video later and an update as I go since, my experience with Delonghi has been tarnished a bit. A 3 in 1 I purchased last year conked on me after 3 months (well the frother did and then the espresso machine part altogether this means the pump went grrrr...that one was way more expensive than this) Anyway, my old Delonghi and this one, although loud and a bit clunky, have been great (so far). My machine with Delonghi before was amazing and lasted over 5 years! I loved it and so far I love this one too!Helpful tipsFor those showing problems, all espresso machines will drip and if you overload grounds the thing won't be able to hold them and you will destroy your machine.Be sure to use fine ground espresso and not regular coffee, you won't get the same beautiful espresso from regular coffee. I grind SB Fench or Espresso roast on 12 on my grinder (very fine).Some of the other machines have a shorter wand for the milk frother but this is just right. If you don't know how to pull milk then look at YouTube there are several how too's there. Also note that before steaming the milk you will likely have to release some water from the wand or your milk will come out flat (that happened the first time I used it, and then I remembered I had to do this with my old machine). Simply put an empty cup, you will not use for milk, under the wand and open the steamer. You'll likely get about 2 tbsps of water. Close it back up, wait for green light and steam. Do not forget to clear the steamer wand before and after foaming your milk.As for the very stiff coffee holder. It's supposed to be hard to twist and as long as you don't overfill the coffee it will be fine! Be sure to tamp the coffee as well...thats what the flat part of the scooper is for.
